III Mathematical interpretation of the Schr√∂dinger equation

III.1 The Schr√∂dinger equation as a differential equation

We can write the stationary Schr√∂dinger equation (29) as

E‚Å¢œà‚Å¢(x)=-‚Ñè22‚Å¢m‚Å¢œà‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Å¢(x)+V‚Å¢(x)‚Å¢œà‚Å¢(x), (31)

where œà‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Å¢(x) denotes the second derivative of the wave function. Equation (31) is a homogeneous linear ordinary differential equation of second order. The solutions œà‚Å¢(x) have the following properties:

Mathematical property I: superposition principle: If œà1‚Å¢(x) and œà2‚Å¢(x) are solutions of Eq.¬†(31) and A, B are constants, then

œà‚Å¢(x)=A‚Å¢œà1‚Å¢(x)+B‚Å¢œà2‚Å¢(x) (32)

is also a solution of Eq.¬†(31). This is a consequence of the linearity of Eq.¬†(31).

Mathematical property II: continuity conditions: Any solution œà‚Å¢(x) is a continuous function (the function is smooth, i.e., has no jumps). The first derivative œà‚Ä≤‚Å¢(x) is also continuous, with the possible exception of points where |V‚Å¢(x)|=‚àû. At such points, œà‚Ä≤‚Å¢(x) may jump, which translates into a ‚Äòkink‚Äô in œà‚Å¢(x) [i.e., œà‚Å¢(x) is still continuous, but suddenly changes its slope].

Mathematical property III: boundary conditions: The wave function must be bounded for |x|‚Üí‚àû (i.e., it is not allowed to increase indefinitely). This condition has a physical origin, since if it were violated we could not interpret |œà‚Å¢(x)|2 as the position probability density (the particle would be sitting at ¬±‚àû).

III.2 The Schr√∂dinger equation as an eigenvalue problem

In general, œà‚Å¢(x) is a function, and H^‚Å¢œà‚Å¢(x) is just another function, which usually is of a very different form than œà‚Å¢(x). In solving the stationary Schr√∂dinger equation, we find functions œàn‚Å¢(x) such that H^‚Å¢œàn=En‚Å¢œàn. Thus, for a solution œàn of the stationary Schr√∂dinger equation the operation with H^ is equivalent to the multiplication by a real number En. Functions œàn‚Å¢(x) with this property are called eigenfunctions of H^, and the numbers En are known as eigenvalues. Informed by the physical meaning of these mathematical objects, the eigenfunctions of the Hamiltonian are also called eigenstates, and since the Hamiltonian represents energy its eigenvalues are called eigenenergies.

III.3 Momentum eigenfunctions

Eigenfunctions and eigenvalues can also be defined for other operators A^, by requiring A^‚Å¢œà=a‚Å¢œà. In particular, the eigenfunctions of the momentum operator p^=-i‚Å¢‚Ñè‚Å¢d/d‚Å¢x are

œàp‚Å¢(x)=12‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢‚Ñè‚Å¢exp‚Å°(i‚Å¢p‚Å¢x/‚Ñè), (33)

and thus are given by the position-dependent part of the plane waves Œ®k [see Eq.¬†(13); the stated form expresses k by the eigenvalue p, and the stated amplitude ensures the appropriate normalisation of the probability distribution of momentum, introduced in Section VII.1].

III.4 Position eigenfunctions and the Dirac delta-function

The eigenfunctions of x^ must be very localised in space, at some place x0, and zero at all other places, so that x^‚Å¢œàx0‚Å¢(x)=x‚Å¢œàx0‚Å¢(x)=x0‚Å¢œàx0‚Å¢(x). These highly singular functions can be expressed in terms of Dirac‚Äôs Œ¥-function,

œàx0‚Å¢(x)=Œ¥‚Å¢(x-x0). (34)

The Œ¥-function is so singular that it actually does not constitute a proper function, but a so-called distribution. Its defining property is the following integral:

‚à´-‚àû‚àûùëëx‚Å¢f‚Å¢(x)‚Å¢Œ¥‚Å¢(x-x0)=f‚Å¢(x0) (35)

for any function f‚Å¢(x) that is continuous at x0. The Œ¥-function is real and symmetric, Œ¥*‚Å¢(x-x‚Ä≤)=Œ¥‚Å¢(x-x‚Ä≤)=Œ¥‚Å¢(x‚Ä≤-x).
Points to remember

  • ‚Ä¢

    The stationary Schr√∂dinger equation is a linear differential equation, and the ensuing superposition principle, continuity requirements and boundary conditions determine important features of its solutions.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The stationary Schr√∂dinger equation can also be interpreted as an eigenvalue equation of the Hamiltonian, H^‚Å¢œà=E‚Å¢œà.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The eigenfunctions of the momentum operator are given by œàp‚Å¢(x)=12‚Å¢œÄ‚Å¢‚Ñè‚Å¢exp‚Å°(i‚Å¢p‚Å¢x/‚Ñè).
